en: Corbès is characterized by a scattered habitat: you will discover there mas spaced out one from the other, of approximately 100 meters. The mas have been built either on the water crossing points (springs) or on the rocky parts of the sites in order to save productive plots of land. From an initial installation, the farmhouses have been enlarged according to the new needs that have arisen, particularly with the spread of silkworm cultivation, where the main buildings have been raised to house the silkworm nurseries. The Mescladou Bridge It was built at the time of the construction of the railway line from Anduze to Saint-Jean-du-Gard at the beginning of the 20th century. It is located at the limit of the communes of Corbès and Générargues. At its foot, one can see the confluence of the Gardons of Saint-Jean and Mialet, a mixture of waters, hence its name ''Mescladou''. The paper mill Located upstream of the Moulin de la Crote (of which only ruins remain), the paper mill is the place where paper was made called ''butcher's shop''. The straw which came from the surrounding villages, especially from the plain of Tornac, was passed to the public weight in Anduze and was then thrown from the roadside to the paper mill below. The lime came from the lime kiln of the Rocher de Peyremale, still visible today on the road to Générargues. 150 bales of straw were melted in a basin, then put into the digester, turned and baked with steam pressure. This mixture, once cooled, was taken to the millstones which transformed it into paste. This paste was crushed to become fluid and then spread on metal sheets covered with felt. The treadmill spun this texture with woollen blankets and the mixture dried in about 5 minutes. Once dry, the mixture became paper and was rolled up on large rolls and sent to the cutter to be cut into 50x50 sheets. The mill also made paper bags and thinner paper made from recycled rags. Le Jardin Clos (1774) Oral tradition tells of a gambling debt contracted by a mason and paid in this very beautiful way, or of a fortune built in the islands by selling slaves. It is a hydraulic ensemble composed of a spring at the bottom of a well associated with a basin constituting a water reserve. It should be noted that the period - end of the reign of Louis XV - was propitious to "follies": it was during this same period that the gardens and basins of the Fountain of Nîmes were designed. The Temple According to the many archives consulted, we can think that the Church of Saint Michel de Corbès was founded by monks from Aniane who had settled in Lasalle and then spread throughout the region. They certainly cleared the surrounding area and created the priory Saint Michel de Corbès. This village which has a lot of charm, will be a beautiful way to discover the Cevennes and its thousand landscapes. For the city of Corbès, the visit of the surroundings must remain a discovery!

en:
Corbès is characterized by a dispersed habitat: you will discover farmhouses spaced out one from the other, of approximately 100 meters. The village has no centre but is surrounded by large cultivated and wild areas.
The farmhouses were built either on the water crossing points (springs) or on the most rocky parts of the sites in order to save the productive plots. On an initial installation, the farmhouses were enlarged according to the new needs which appeared, in particular with the deployment of the culture of the silkworm where the principal buildings were heightened in order to shelter the magnaneries

The Mescladou Bridge
It was built at the time of the construction of the railway line from Anduze to Saint-Jean-du-Gard at the beginning of the 20th century. It is located at the limit of the communes of Corbès and Générargues. At its foot, you can see the confluence of the Gardons of Saint-Jean and Mialet, mixing waters, hence its name ''Mescladou''.

The paper mill
Located upstream from the Moulin de la Crote (of which only ruins remain), the paper mill is the place where the so-called "butcher's paper" was made. It is a rather crude paper, yellow brown, which was made from lime, straw and old paper.
The straw, which came from the surrounding communes, especially from the plain of Tornac, was weighed down in Anduze and then thrown from the roadside to the paper mill below. The lime came from the lime kiln of the Rocher de Peyremale, still visible today on the road to Générargues.

The lime was melted in a basin, then 150 bales of straw were put into the digester, which was turned and cooked by steam pressure. This mixture, once cooled, was taken to the millstones which transformed it into paste. This paste was crushed to become fluid and then spread on metal sheets covered with felt. The conveyor belt wrung out this texture with wool blankets and the mixture dried in about 5 minutes. Once dry, the mixture was rolled onto large rolls and sent to the cutting machine where it was cut into 50x50 sheets
The factory also made paper bags and thinner paper made from recycled rags.
The Closed Garden (1774)
The oral tradition speaks of a gambling debt contracted by a mason and paid off in this very beautiful way, or of a fortune built in the islands by selling slaves. It is a hydraulic complex composed of a spring captured at the bottom of a well associated with a basin constituting a water reserve. Note that the period - the end of the reign of Louis XV - was conducive to "follies": it was during this same period that the gardens and basins of the Fountain of Nimes were designed.

The Temple
According to the numerous archives consulted, we can think that the Church of Saint Michel de Corbès was founded by monks from Aniane who had settled in Lasalle and then spread throughout the region. They certainly cleared the land around them and created the priory of Saint Michel de Corbès.

This village, which has a lot of charm, will be a good place to discover the Cevennes and its thousand landscapes.
For the town of Corbès, the visit of the surroundings must remain a discovery!

Corbès se caractérise par un habitat dispersé : vous y découvrirez des mas espacés les uns des autres, d'environ 100 mètres. La commune n'a pas de centre mais est elle est entourée de grands espaces cultivées et sauvages.
Les mas ont été construits soit sur les points de passage d'eau (les sources), soit sur les parties les plus rocheuses des sites afin d'économiser les parcelles productives. Sur une installation initiale, les mas se sont agrandis en fonction des nouveaux besoins qui apparaissaient, notamment avec le déploiement de la culture du vers à soie où les bâtisses principales ont été rehaussées afin d'abriter les magnaneries. 

Le Pont du Mescladou
Il a été réalisé au moment de la construction de la ligne de chemin de fer d'Anduze à Saint-Jean-du-Gard au début du XXème siècle. Il se situe à la limite des communes de Corbès et de Générargues. A son pied, on peut apercevoir la confluence des Gardons de Saint-Jean et de Mialet, mélange des eaux, d'où son nom ''Mescladou''.

La papeterie
Située en amont du Moulin de la Crote (dont il ne reste que des ruines), la papeterie est le lieu où l'on fabriquait du papier dit de ''boucherie''. C'est un papier assez fruste, marron jaune, qui était fait à base de chaux, de paille et de vieux papiers récupérés.
La paille qui venait des communes environnantes, surtout de la plaine de Tornac, passait au poids public à Anduze puis elle était lancée depuis le bord de la route jusqu’à la papeterie en contre-bas. La chaux venait du four à chaux du Rocher de Peyremale, encore visible de nos jours sur la route de Générargues.

On faisait fondre la chaux dans un bassin, on mettait ensuite dans le lessiveur 150 ballots de paille que l’on faisait tourner puis que l’on faisait cuire avec la pression de la vapeur. Ce mélange, une fois refroidit était emmené aux meules qui le transformait en pâte. Cette pâte était broyée pour devenir fluide et ensuite répandue sur des feuilles de métal recouverte de feutre. Le tapis roulant essorait cette texture avec des couvertures de laine et le mélange séchait en environ 5 minutes. Une fois sec, ce mélange devenu papier était enroulé sur des gros rouleaux et partait vers la coupeuse qui en faisait des feuilles de 50x50. 
L’usine fabriquait aussi des sacs en papier et du papier plus fin fait avec des chiffons de récupérations.
Le Jardin Clos (1774)
La tradition orale parle d'une dette de jeu contractée par un maçon et acquittée de cette fort belle manière, ou encore d'une fortune bâtie dans les îles par la vente d'esclaves. C'est un ensemble hydraulique composé d'une source captée au fond d'un puits associée à un bassin constituant une réserve d'eau. Notons que l'époque – fin du règne de Louis XV – était propice aux "folies" : c'est à cette même période que furent dessinés les jardins et les bassins de la Fontaine de Nîmes.

Le Temple 
D'après les nombreuses archives consultées, on peut penser que l'Église Saint Michel de Corbès a été fondée par des moines venus d'Aniane qui s'étaient implantés à Lasalle et qui ont ensuite essaimé dans toute la région. Ils ont certainement défriché aux alentours et crée le prieuré Saint Michel de Corbès.

Ce village qui a beaucoup de charme, sera un beau passage pour découvrir les Cévennes et ses mille paysages.
Pour la ville de Corbès, la visite des environs doit rester une découverte !
